												America's Army 3:Positives:+ Free download, doesn't cost a cent!+ Great community, many of whom are mature aged gamers using microphone to communicate. A real team based First Person Shooter which rewards players for helping each other. For example, the faster you medic teammates, the less damage they will take to a limb when they've been shot in that area. + Realistic firing mechanics. When an enemy is shooting at you, aiming becomes much more difficult and guns are not always 100% accurate. + Most maps are small, which would traditionally be viewed negatively. However, this complements America's Army 3 because it allows players to become experienced with the environments, memorise key spots and provide accurate communication to teammates without confusion.+ Decent graphics, could be better though.+ A First Person Shooter which actually concentrates on skill, quick reflexes, constantly assessing your decisions and leaning around corners instead of blindly charging in like Call of Duty. The game is tactical but fun, deploying smoke grenades and flashbangs at the right time is useful, but they're balanced and not overpowered.+ Steep learning curve. This is a game for true First Person Shooter players. It isn't for the impatient or those who want to "respawn". Once you die for the round, you're out. So the game is about survival and teamwork, not personal glory and "leet solo skills". That said, it would be a mistake to compare this title to ARMA or Operation Flashpoint games. There will still be times when you are the last man standing and need to hunt down the enemy against the odds - good fun.Negatives:- With the release of America's Army: Proving Grounds, the sequel to America's Army 3, this game lost a large proportion of its community. In fact, the entire Australian group has left, and there remains only a few servers of dedicated American veterans with a love for the game. So, if you're from the United States and interested in this game, give it a go.- Limited weapon selection. The developers did this to reflect real-life military loadouts, but you aren't even given a pistol or knife as a secondary weapon. There are two main guns in the game, the M249 SAW and the M16/M4A1, with optional optic sights. Not a great amount of variety there. Overall Score: 8.5/10America's Army 3 is an underrated gem. Having played it over the course of a few years in excess of 1,000 hours, I can honestly say this game has huge replayability. Definitely download it.

												Alright, let's talk about America's Army 3. If you haven't already guessed, it's the third installment. Coming from America's Army 2, it's a slight let down. That said, the game does have far better mechanics then it's predecessor (AA2), and even it's successor (Proving Grounds). It has all the mandatory and fundamental features/mechanics you expect from a tactical shooter. The game has a very authentic feel when playing it tactically. However, all that falls apart because of the poor server performance, terrible netcode, and inconsistent hit detection; sometimes you'll slay everyone left and right, and other times your weapon appears to be firing blanks.Because of that, the game ends up benefitting from a more aggressive, run & gun style of play. So you'll see players firing in fully automatic, spraying down targets, strafing back and forth, spamming grenades, and so on. If you're the kind of guy (like me), that takes things slower, covering every angle and watching every corner, you should come out on top. But when it comes to shot placement, it's very inconsistent. You'll be the one to take accurate, semi-automatic fire at an enemy, and he'll spray back at you, and more often than not, he'll win the firefight, strictly based on the poor hit detection. Even though you line up those shots perfectly center mass, they'll feel like they do nothing at all, and even if you do win that engagement, chances are you were wounded in the process.In short, this is an incredible game hampered down by those issues. If it was well polished, bug free, and had excellent online server performance, this game would be amazing. I want to love this game. I really do. It is an addicting game, with interesting gamemodes, and realistic weapon handling and maneuvering.The reason why I'm recommending this game, is because it's FREE. It costs you nothing, and it's a decent experience. But you'll no doubt see the potential the game has, and wish it was better in all those areas I covered. Even with all its faults, I prefer it considerably over that of Proving Grounds, which in my opinion is an abhorrent game and a disgrace to the America's Army series.If you want to see what AA2 was all about, look up "25Assist." It's a community made effort to bring America's Army 2.5 back to life, and has been running since around 2010. If the same love and care that was applied to 25Assist was applied here for AA3, it would no doubt be one of the best tactical shooters out there.In the end, it's fun, and you may enjoy it, but you'll just keep thinking about how much better it could be.

 America's Army 3If you're looking for CoD or Battlefield, stay away from this title. If you want standard FPS play, stay away from this title. If you want to charge into battle Rambo style, play this game--but not on my team. If you are curious about military service or interested in a serious attempt at simulating combat where wounds are not typically superficial and team-oriented play is a must, this may be the game for you. It's aging a bit now, and the game's community/development has been replaced by that CoD wannabe pretending to be an America's Army game. BUT this is still a great game. If you try it and like it, you might even see if you can get a copy of America's Army 2: Special Forces, as in some respects I think that was a superior version. The AI on it, some of the training, and especially the special forces training section can help anyone improve their FPS game--regardless of what game you regularly play. That being said, it does have limitations in areas that some other pay to play games do better. However, fewer jumpy Halo types to annoy--either because they're too chicken to play games like this or because they have enough sense to adapt their style to this game. That right there makes it worth playing in my opinion.All in All  America's Army 3	 is a good FPS Game!7/10 From Me Sweep

You play either as the US Army or as the Opposing Force who are generic baddies. The teams battle for various objectives on a variety of maps with an array of real and fictional weapons - the fictional weapons are used only by the Opposing Force. There are plenty of problems, such as glitchy animations and weapons bugs. Posted: April 7, 2015
												AA3 stands apart from mainstream shooters like Call of Duty for one reason: it's very much a team-oriented game.  If you're a fan of COD (I happen to like COD, Battlefield, and CS), you'll find that the gameplay style here is significantly different.  Yes, there are some players that like to run and gun, but for the most part, this is a game that requires you to move slower and have more patience.  Having a mic for this game is a must, if you want to get the most out of it.In AA3, there are no respawns.  You have an objective, which, depending on the game mode, could involve securing points, grabbing a suitcase and bringing it to a point, or escorting a VIP to an extraction point.AA3 also feels very different than Proving Grounds.  Much more teamwork in this game, far fewer players running around solo and dying in 15 seconds.Pros:- It's free.- It's team-oriented.  Regular players use VOIP to call out enemy locations, so a team with mics will annilihate a team without them.- There is a pretty cool medic system.  Getting shot affects your movement differently if it's in your arm vs in your leg.  You can treat injured teammates, but have to apply the correct treatment.  (Sadly, there are only 4 possible treatments, so ultimately you just have to memorize those 4).- If you're not good at twitch shooters and like something more tactical, this is for you.Cons:- There are bugs. 												One of the best F2P titles I have ever played - and one of the extremely few that are actually completely free.You have to keep in mind this game was designed to get young people to sign up with the US Army, so if you have amoral problem with supporting that, rather stay clear of it.I hadn´t, and I´ve had a lot of fun for a lot of time.I´d characterize this game as ARMA 3, but mixed with CoD MW2 in a mixture of 3:1.One of the most important aspects is its semi-realistic gunplay and overall feel. It´s one of those rare games where you can actually feel the weight of your character, the recoil of the gun, the inertia of the bullet and other physics-related impression.This creates a lot of immersion, but will make it rather challenging for new players, that haven´t played a (semi-)sim (or "Simcade") recently. However, you will get a very detailed tutorial, which you can play whenever you like (I hate it when a game forces you to play a tutorial, and then you can´t revisit it for the remainder of the game). Very well executed.This, together with the above average learning of the control scheme, reminded me a lot of ARMA. The graphics and sounds are both very well made for the time, and they still hold up to todays standards.Now to the CoD-like aspect. The maps are predominantly medium-sized, maybe think of Array from Black Ops 1. This means you still get to fight at a distance, which is essential for the realistic feel, while you still encounter lots of enemies to be constantly challenged.Just as in CoD and BF, you unlock most of the more interesting guns through gameplay, which might be too grindy for casual players, but will keep anyone with a good amount of time on their hands occupied for quite some time.I like the different game-modes. While they are nothing too innovative, you still have very distinct gameplay differences between the different modes, instead of just "shooting as usual, but stopping to cap a flag occasionally". Every mode actually feels different enough to stay interesting over longer periods of time.This game can be played either competitively (everything you play, from the tutorial to the hardcore challenges is timed and objectively scored, so you can literally compete in anything you like with your friends) or rather casually (games are quick to jump in and out of). that´s a plus in my book.Overall: 8/10, definitely recommended. And a must-have for everyone who enjoys the more convoluted gameplay if ARMA.
